  • Heterogeneous/ Multi-Modal

Heterogeneous/ Multi-ModalÔÉÅ

Binary Classification of Galaxy Morphologies Using Images Paired with Tabular Metadata.

Mixed data analysis is one of the areas where deep learning really sets itself apart from traditional forms of statistics and machine learning. Neural networks are an effective way to logically encode and combine any type of data (image, text, time series, audio, tabular spreadsheets, video, etc) within the same analysis while converging toward the minimization a single loss metric. This leads to rich experiments that resemble real-world scenarios that resemble man-machine symbiosis. For example, consider combining a doctor‚Äôs annotations with electronic medical records and histology imagery.

This example was put together for a demo that builds upon the documentation of the Low-Level API and the example workflows for binary classification. Due to the fact that these images were captured by different instruments that represent color differently, I removed the noisy 3-channel color information and proceeded with grayscale. Since the shapes of the features are dynamically passed into the model, the only difference between a single versus multi-channel workflow is changing the actual layers (e.g.¬†``Conv1D`` to ``Conv2D``).

[ ]:

import aiqc
from aiqc import datum

[ ]:

from sklearn.preprocessing import *
import keras
from keras.models import Sequential, Model
from keras import layers
import tensorflow as tf

Ingesting Example Galaxy DataÔÉÅ

Tabular DataÔÉÅ

[199]:

df = datum.to_pandas('galaxies.tsv')

Using the built-in structured data about 40 galaxies, we‚Äôll derive:

  • A binary, categorical label: morphology.

  • Categorical and numeric metadata features: clarity, angle.

  • A manifest detailing where to find our image files: url.

[200]:

df.head(3)

[200]:
morphology clarity angle url
0 bar 0 face https://raw.githubusercontent.com/aiqc/aiqc/ma...
1 bar 3 angle https://raw.githubusercontent.com/aiqc/aiqc/ma...
2 bar 3 face https://raw.githubusercontent.com/aiqc/aiqc/ma...

From a single Dataset.Tabular we‚Äôll specify a Label and Feature before encoding them.

[9]:

dataset_tab = aiqc.Dataset.Tabular.from_pandas(df)

[12]:

label = dataset_tab.make_label(columns=['morphology'])

[14]:

label.make_labelcoder(sklearn_preprocess=OrdinalEncoder())

    sklearn_preprocess = StandardScaler(),
    columns = ['clarity']
)

Image DataÔÉÅ

Construct a Dataset.Image from that manifest and use it as a 2nd Feature.

urls = df['url'].tolist()

dataset_img = aiqc.Dataset.Image.from_urls(urls)

Bar galaxies

[189]:

example_images[15]

[218]:

example_images[0]

[218]:

Although it is easy enough to distinguish between the two types with the naked eye, you start to realize that a bar galaxy is almost like a degraded spiral galaxy. Like anything else, there is a gray area in whether or not the band of stars/ rectangle of light connecting the two main galactic arms is to be considered a ‚Äúbar‚Äù or more of an oval.

Spiral galaxies

[193]:

[31]:

feature_img = dataset_img.make_feature()

We have only 40 samples, so we‚Äôll keep our validation and test splits small, and definitely forgo cross-validation.

Notice how we pass in both the tabular and image Features. As described in the low-level API documentation, the first feature in the list is used to determine stratification.

[32]:

splitset = aiqc.Splitset.make(
    feature_ids = [feature_tab.id, feature_img.id]
    , label_id = label.id
    , size_validation = 0.125
    , size_test = 0.175
)

Defining a ModelÔÉÅ

AIQC makes it easy to compartmentalize both Keras/TensorFlow and PyTorch models. See Algorithm in the Low-Level API documentation.

Hyperparameters are passed in as the hp** kwargs, which allows you to tweak both the topology and the params alike.

Below we see two towers, feedforward for tabular data and convolutional for image data, that are eventually concatenated together.

[35]:

def fn_build(feature_shapes, label_shape, **hp):

    # Feed forward tower using the first Feature.
    ff_input = layers.Input(shape=feature_shapes[0][0])
    ff = layers.Dense(units=hp['ff_neurons'], activation='relu')(ff_input)
    ff = layers.Dropout(0.2)(ff)
    model_ff = Model(ff_input, ff)

    # Convolutional tower using the second Feature.
    cnn_input = layers.Input(shape=feature_shapes[1])
    cnn = layers.Conv1D(
        16*hp['cnn_multiply'], kernel_size=3,
        padding='same', activation='relu',
        kernel_initializer=hp['init'])(cnn_input)
    #cnn = layers.MaxPooling1D(pool_size=2)(cnn)
    cnn = layers.BatchNormalization()(cnn)
    cnn = layers.Dropout(hp['dropout'])(cnn)

    cnn = layers.Conv1D(
        16*hp['cnn_multiply'], kernel_size=3,
        padding='same', activation='relu',
        kernel_initializer=hp['init'])(cnn)
    #cnn = layers.MaxPooling1D(pool_size=2)(cnn)
    cnn = layers.BatchNormalization()(cnn)
    cnn = layers.Dropout(hp['dropout'])(cnn)

    cnn = layers.Conv1D(
        32*hp['cnn_multiply'], kernel_size=3,
        padding='same', activation='relu',
        kernel_initializer=hp['init'])(cnn)
    #cnn = layers.MaxPooling1D(pool_size=2)(cnn)
    cnn = layers.BatchNormalization()(cnn)
    cnn = layers.Dropout(hp['dropout'])(cnn)

    if (hp['4th_cnn'] == True):
        cnn = layers.Conv1D(
            32*hp['cnn_multiply'], kernel_size=3,
            padding='same', activation='relu',
            kernel_initializer=hp['init'])(cnn)
        #cnn = layers.MaxPooling1D(pool_size=2)(cnn)
        cnn = layers.BatchNormalization()(cnn)
        cnn = layers.Dropout(hp['dropout'])(cnn)

    # Perform one dense layer on CNN output, so that the tabular data
    # can talk directly to the
    cnn = layers.Flatten()(cnn)
    cnn = layers.BatchNormalization()(cnn)
    cnn = layers.Activation('relu')(cnn)
    cnn = layers.Dropout(0.2)(cnn)
    model_cnn = Model(cnn_input, cnn)

    concat = layers.concatenate([model_ff.output, model_cnn.output])
    join = layers.Dense(hp['concat_neurons'], activation='relu')(concat)
    join = layers.BatchNormalization()(join)
    join = layers.Activation('relu')(join)
    join = layers.Dropout(0.2)(join)

    join = layers.Dense(label_shape[0], activation='sigmoid')(join)


    model = Model(inputs=[model_ff.input, model_cnn.input], outputs=join)
    return model

[108]:

def fn_train(model, loser, optimizer, samples_train, samples_evaluate, **hp):
    model.compile(
        loss = loser
        , optimizer = optimizer
        , metrics = ['accuracy']
    )

    # Early stopper.
    metrics_cuttoffs = [
        {"metric":"accuracy", "cutoff":0.90, "above_or_below":"above"},
        {"metric":"val_accuracy", "cutoff":0.80, "above_or_below":"above"}, #5 samples in validation set.
    ]
    cutoffs = aiqc.TrainingCallback.Keras.MetricCutoff(metrics_cuttoffs)
    callbacks=[keras.callbacks.History(), cutoffs]


    model.fit(
        x = samples_train["features"]
        , y = samples_train["labels"]
        , validation_data = (
            samples_evaluate["features"]
            , samples_evaluate["labels"]
        )
        , verbose = 0
        , batch_size = hp['batch_size']
        , epochs = hp['epoch_count']
        , callbacks=callbacks
    )
    return model

You can also customize the functions for loss, optimization, and prediction - but we‚Äôll just run with the defaults for binary classification analysis.

[109]:

algorithm = aiqc.Algorithm.make(
    library = "keras"
    , analysis_type = "classification_binary"
    , fn_build = fn_build
    , fn_train = fn_train

    , fn_lose = None
    , fn_optimize = None
    , fn_predict = None
)

Define the parameters that will be passed in as the hp** argument in the functions above.

[110]:

hyperparameters = {
    "epoch_count": [300]
    , "learning_rate": [0.01]
    , "batch_size": [5]

    , "ff_neurons": [5]

    , "cnn_multiply": [1.0, 0.5]
    , "dropout": [0.5]
    , "init": ['he_normal']
    , "4th_cnn": [True]

    , "concat_neurons": [64]
}

[111]:

hyperparamset = algorithm.make_hyperparamset(
    hyperparameters = hyperparameters
)

Train ModelsÔÉÅ

repeat_count runs the same model multiple times due to the fact that neural networks are non-deterministic.

[112]:

queue = algorithm.make_queue(
    splitset_id = splitset.id
    , hyperparamset_id = hyperparamset.id
    , repeat_count = 5
)

[113]:

tf.get_logger().setLevel('ERROR');

[114]:

queue.run_jobs()

Interpret ResultsÔÉÅ

The boomerang chart shows how each model performed across all of its splits [and or folds].

[ ]:

queue.plot_performance(
    max_loss = 3.0, min_accuracy = 0.70
)

Let‚Äôs dig into that green model with precise loss.

[132]:

predictor = aiqc.Predictor.get_by_id(26)

[133]:

predictor.get_hyperparameters(as_pandas=True)

[133]:
param value
0 epoch_count 300
1 learning_rate 0.01
2 batch_size 5
3 ff_neurons 5
4 cnn_multiply 1.0
5 dropout 0.5
6 init he_normal
7 4th_cnn True
8 concat_neurons 64

Not exactly the smoothest curve, and it seems like we could have learned more with a bit of patience, but, then again, it always seems that way.

[ ]:

predictor.plot_learning_curve(loss_skip_15pct=True)

The charts below show how it performed when running predictions against each split in the dataset.

[140]:

prediction = predictor.predictions[0]

[ ]:

prediction.plot_roc_curve()

Interestingly enough, the model is performing poorly on the training split. I guess that‚Äôs what you get when you set dropout=0.5. You can tell that it hasn‚Äôt learned all of the spiral patterns yet by examining the matrix.

[ ]:

prediction.plot_confusion_matrix()

[ ]:

prediction.plot_precision_recall()

We have all of the metrics for every run precalculated and at our disposal.

[161]:

queue.metrics_aggregate_to_pandas()

We can also inspect the actual predictions for each split, which have been automatically inverse_transform‚Äôed back from their encoded values.

[9]:

       dtype=object),

Let‚Äôs dig into our recorded experiment to pull out the samples within the training set that were misclassified by comparing them to their actual labels.

[14]:

train_predicted = predictor.predictions[0].predictions['train']

[12]:

train_samples = predictor.job.queue.splitset.samples['train']

[19]:

train_actual = predictor.job.queue.splitset.label.to_numpy(samples=train_samples).flatten()

[21]:

comparison = train_predicted == train_actual

[34]:

import numpy as np

[34]:

train_misclassifications = np.argwhere(comparison==False).flatten().tolist()

[35]:

train_samples_miss = [train_samples[miss] for miss in train_misclassifications]

[48]:

img_miss = aiqc.Dataset.Image.to_pillow(id=2, samples=train_samples_miss)

Here is an example of a spiral that was missclassified as a bar.
